newsitem.title: UK: U.S. airliner diverted after bomb scare.
newsitem.headline: U.S. airliner diverted after bomb scare.

text.p: A U.S. airliner landed safely at Glasgow airport on Wednesday after a bomb scare forced it to divert in mid-Atlantic.
The American Airlines' Boeing 767, on a flight from London to Chicago with 193 people on board, was 500 miles (800 km) west of Ireland when it diverted to the Scottish city of Glasgow.
Fire engines and police gathered by the plane, which was searched for a possible suspect package.
But police said later the airliner had been diverted because of a "malicious" hoaxer.
A scribbled note found in a seat pocket of the airliner was drawn to the attention of a flight attendant and the captain decided to turn back to Glasgow, the nearest airport.
It was the hoax that prompted a major security operation. For the last leg of its journey, the airliner was shadowed by a British air force Boeing Sentry radar surveillance aircraft.
Rescue helicopters stood by, but the plane landed safely without them needing to be called on, officials said.
American said the 179 passengers and 14 crew would continue their journey on the airliner once it was given clearance.
